sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The Debtford frollick; or, A hue and cry after the shag-breeches. Young vvoman all, both great and small, that handleth pot or pail, for some I hear, and greatly fear. Do oft play with their tayl. Tune of, The fair one let me in.
1 sheet ([1] p.) : ill. (woodcuts).
Printed for P. Brooksby at the Golden Ball in Pye-corner., [London] : [between 1683-1695]
Verse: "One night when blustering winds blew ..." Place and date of publication suggested by Wing. Trimmed. Reproduction of original in the British Library.
=======
The Debtford frollick; or, A hue and cry after the shag-breeches. Young vvoman all, both great and small, that handleth pot or pail, for some I hear, and greatly fear. Do oft play with their tayl. Tune of, The fair one let me in.
1 sheet ([1] p.) : ill. (woodcuts).
Printed for P. Brooksby at the Golden Ball in Pye-corner., [London] : [between 1683-1695]
Verse: "One night when blustering winds blew ..." Place and date of publication suggested by Wing. Trimmed. Reproduction of original in the British Library.
P. Brooksby
the Golden Ball in Pye-corner.
